quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 4 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 4.9: Ionization Energy and Electron Affinity
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Energy trends in the periodic table

questions.question: What is the definition of 'First Ionization Energy'?
options: The energy required to remove the most loosely held electron from a neutral atom.
The energy released when an atom gains an electron.
The energy required to add a proton to the nucleus.
The total energy of all electrons in the ground state.
questions.explanation: Ionization energy measures how strongly an atom holds onto its electrons; higher values mean the electron is harder to remove.

questions.question: As you move from left to right across a period, ionization energy generally:
questions.explanation: Because the nuclear charge increases and the atomic radius decreases, the nucleus exerts a stronger pull on electrons, making them harder to remove.

questions.question: Why does ionization energy decrease as you move down a group?
options: Electrons are further from the nucleus and shielded by inner shells.
There are fewer protons to pull on the electrons.
The atoms are becoming more stable.
questions.explanation: As more energy levels are added, the valence electrons are further away and experience more 'shielding' from inner electrons, making them easier to remove.

questions.question: Which group of elements has the highest ionization energies?
questions.explanation: Noble gases have a stable octet and a high effective nuclear charge for their period, making them very resistant to losing electrons.

questions.question: What is 'Electron Affinity'?
options: The energy change that occurs when an electron is acquired by a neutral atom.
The force of gravity between two atoms.
The energy required to move an electron to a higher orbit.
The speed at which an electron orbits the nucleus.
questions.explanation: Electron affinity measures how much an atom 'wants' an electron; most nonmetals release energy when they gain one.

questions.question: Which of the following elements would likely have the highest (most negative) electron affinity?
questions.explanation: Halogens like Fluorine are one electron away from a full shell and have a strong nuclear pull, making electron gain highly favorable.

questions.question: Second and third ionization energies are always __________ than the first ionization energy.
questions.explanation: Once one electron is removed, the remaining electrons experience less repulsion and a stronger relative pull from the nucleus.

questions.question: A massive 'jump' in ionization energy occurs when:
options: An electron is removed from a stable, inner-shell noble gas configuration.
questions.explanation: Removing a 'core' electron requires significantly more energy than removing a valence electron because core electrons are much closer to the nucleus.

questions.question: Which of the following elements has the lowest first ionization energy?
questions.explanation: Cesium is a large atom with many shells, so its single valence electron is very far from the nucleus and easily lost.

questions.question: In general, nonmetals have __________ ionization energies and __________ electron affinities than metals.
questions.explanation: Nonmetals hold their electrons tightly (high ionization energy) and actively attract new ones (high electron affinity).
